data.review:
Man. What an absolute blast. I understand the issues those who don’t like Solo Leveling have with the show. The plot so far has mainly been a vehicle instead of a driver so to speak. It simply does just enough to allow the strengths of the show to really shine through. There are really three reasons to watch this show that can sum up where my enjoyment lies. ANIMATION The animation of each fight in season 2 scaled from very good to amazing (except maybe the Baran fight. The grey cloak with the added rain did make it hard to see what was happening at somepoints and IMO was the least aesthetically pleasing fight).

POWER FANTASY
Solo Leveling does a great job with one thing in this aspect: FUN. It is fun to watch Jinwoo exponentially grow stronger over the course of this season. He scales from a lower tier hunter to one of the best in the country and it is very satisfying to watch. No MC struggling or gaining power from anger or friendship, just the system helping him out!


And lastly AURA FARMING
Yes, as goofy as it sounds, the memes are true. Jinwoo is the ultimate badass and commands attention in very impactful scenes in this season. He was the highlight of an entire episode that he was only in for 3 seconds! He is fun to pull for and it never gets old watching him show up and save the day. He’s the polar opposite of Saitama. We get to see how everyone else is amazed by Jinwoo’s capabilities and it’s so cool.

I’d also like to add unlike isekai’s where the MC is teleported to another world and is super strong, Jineoo isn’t running around with 5 women at all times which is nice to see. There are women who admire him, but there are men in the show who admire him as well!

In my opinion, Solo Leveling isn’t some think piece anime in the likes of DevilMan Crybaby or Cyberpunk Edgerunners. It is pure fun. At the very least, you can turn your brain off and enjoy pulling for an MC that really takes on the role of the “I am strong and I know it” attitude.

entry.title: Ore dake Level Up na Ken Season 2: Arise from the Shadow

data.review:
“A haunting masterpiece that left me emotionally drained.” Grave of the Fireflies is one of the most emotionally devastating anime films I've ever seen. It’s not an easy watch, and honestly, it wasn’t meant to be. This is a powerful, tragic story about two siblings trying to survive in war-torn Japan, and the film pulls no punches in showing the harsh realities they face. I gave it an 8/10 because while it’s absolutely masterful in its storytelling and visual direction, it was incredibly difficult to get through. The sadness hits you hard and lingers long after the credits roll. Watching the bond between Seita and Setsuko slowlyunravel as hope fades was heartbreaking. The innocence of childhood being crushed under the weight of war—it’s just... heavy.

The animation is beautiful and subtle, which only adds to the impact. Every quiet moment feels meaningful, every firefly a symbol of fleeting life. I appreciate that it doesn’t rely on dramatics—it’s the simple, honest depiction of loss and love that makes it so devastating.

It’s not a film I’ll rewatch anytime soon, but I’m glad I experienced it. Grave of the Fireflies isn’t just an anime—it’s a deeply human story that forces you to sit with grief, and in that, it becomes unforgettable.

After finishing Nihon e Youkoso Elf-san, I just sat there for a moment, staring at the screen, not fully ready to leave that world behind. This anime wasn’t just entertaining—it felt personal. I went into it expecting a typical fantasy setup, maybe a few laughs, some light action… but what I got was something way more meaningful. The story slowly wraps around you, not with epic battles or crazy twists, but with warmth, quiet emotions, and characters that genuinely feel alive. It’s one of those rare shows that doesn’t scream for your attention, but instead whispers gently and leaves a lasting impression. Let me start withKazuhiro – our MC. He’s not your usual overpowered, loud, “I’m gonna save the world!” type. He’s quiet, a little broken honestly, just trying to get by. His backstory really tugged at me… abandoned by his parents, finding some peace with his grandpa, and using sleep as a coping mechanism to escape reality. That hit close to home for me. There were nights in my own life when I just wanted to shut everything out and dream. I think a lot of us have been there at some point. And this anime somehow... understood that feeling.

And then there’s Mariabelle. God. Where do I even begin? She’s the kind of character that doesn’t just walk into your screen – she walks into your heart. Beautiful, kind, a little naive in a good way, and so full of warmth. Her smile literally made me smile, and I don’t say that often. I could write paragraphs trying to describe her charm, but nothing I say will do her justice. You just have to see her.

There’s this one hilarious moment when she suddenly appears in Kazuhiro’s room and he’s freaking out, and I just burst out laughing. Like, full-on ugly laugh. The comedy in this anime is so natural – not forced or over-the-top – and I appreciate that.

Oh, and Wridra! The voice actress did such a fantastic job. She's got that dignified presence but then suddenly goes full puff-cheek mode when asking for something sweet. I rewound a few scenes just to hear that again. Adorable.

The whole cat-person Mewi being treated like a literal cat by Mariabelle? Too cute. Like, I almost teared up during one scene just because of how wholesome it was. This anime doesn’t rely on big fights or drama – it just gives you comfort. It’s like a warm cup of cocoa on a rainy day.

What I really loved though… was the core concept. The idea that your dreams are actually real. That you’re living a whole other life in another world when you sleep. And that girl you meet there, the adventures you have… they all mean something. I’ve daydreamed about that exact thing since I was a kid. Watching this anime made it feel like someone out there got it – that maybe I wasn’t alone in wishing for that kind of escape.

I swear, when episode 12 ended, I just sat there. Staring. Empty. That kind of post-anime void where you're just not ready to say goodbye. I actually whispered “That’s it?” out loud. I wish there was more. I need more.

To the creators – if by some miracle you ever read this: Thank you. Thank you for crafting something so heartfelt, something that feels like a gentle hug to the lonely parts of us. Please, please give us a Season 2. You’ve created a world we’re not ready to leave.

Princess Tutu is a 2002 anime starring (At the time) fairly new seiyuu, some who would eventually become fairly big in the industry. It existed in the context of the post-1997 anime industry which, due to the massive success of Evangelion, began to bet more into shorter (One to two cour) anime with more experimental stories while also embracing the innovations of digital animation - and in that regard, Princess Tutu's artstyle wouldn't feel out of place were it released five or even ten years later. This anime is WESTERN, but not western in the sense of "Anime largely based on western cinema ans sensibilities" asone would call anime made by Watanabe Shinichirou, nor western in the sense of "A cowboy story", but western in the sense that it not only is about the western cannon of theater, ballet, fairy tales and opera, is also structurally shapes itself around those aesthetically: The anime episodes not only represent an opera, THEY ARE, themselves, an opera.
That in itself makes it a bit hard to analyze it, as it is something that is best "felt", rather than "described with words".

It's arc structure is a bit unorthodox: It's first 13 episodes could themselves alone, with little to no changes, be a complete anime, and one that I would likely give a 10/10. It's second half isn't as strong or concise, but it still found interesting ways of expanding the story.
The anime is strongly episodic, with the episodes (Mainly in it's first half) having little to sometimes no epilogues to them (Sometimes the credits rolling right after the end of the climax), but it still manages to have some sense of progression via the relationships between the characters and the "heart shard" system, which brings visible change to our male lead, Mytho/Myuuto. The "abandonment" of such system in it's third quarter makes it a failure on trying to emulate it's first quarter, as some of it's episodes might now feel a bit repetitive and could easily have swapped places without anyone noticing, the stories themselves also feeling weaker, as they're not based on any specific emotion theme anymore, and it takes a while to get accustomed to that slower pacing after the aggressive spectacle of it's second quarter.

It had a fairly smart way of omitting and drip-feeding information, causing the audience to assume different things as different times (Such as the identity of the raven). Likewise, the decision to focus on different characters in different moments also leads to the relationships the anime will end up with to feel "natural" and "fairly earned".
It's somewhat funny that our "secondary protagonists", with time, end up becoming the focus: The character development of the mysterious Fakir, the tragedy of Rue, too weak to deal with sadness, falling to her darkest desires, feeling empowered by them... but alas, still being a human, we go back to seeing the fragility in her.

Being an anime of which one of the messages is using dance to convey that which cannot be conveyed with words, the series itself conveys with artistry in a way that can only be experiences, and not simply read in a review, it's a marriage between song, dance, theater and animation.

Yo, I’m not the best at writing reviews, so bear with me here. This hentai from Bunny Walker (or T-Rex, same vibes) is hands-down one of the best I’ve seen. Seriously, it’s a gem. Story: 10/10 The plot blew me away—probably the strongest I’ve ever seen in a hentai. It’s got that family dynamic with a mother and sister that just hits different. I’d kill for more stories like this. Art: 10/10 The artwork is straight-up gorgeous, and the animation quality is top-tier. None of that Queen Bee sketchiness here—it’s clean, crisp, and a total feast for the eyes. Animation: 10/10 What else do you expect from Bunny Walker or T-Rex? Theseguys are the kings of hentai animation. Smooth, polished, and just perfection.
Scenes: 10/10
The scenes were fire. I was hoping for a bit more focus on the mother with better angles, but honestly, everything else was so good I can’t complain. Still loved every second.
Characters: 10/10
The characters are what made this stand out. The milf mom and the sisters? Absolute MVPs. They’ve got charm, and I was hooked from start to finish.
Overall: 10/10
This is peak hentai, no question. It’s pure vanilla goodness—zero NTR, no creepy ugly bastards, just wholesome romance with killer art and animation. I had a blast watching it, and you will too. Highly recommend giving it a shot!

Created/animated pretty much entirely by Shinkai. I see now that he is pretty much in charge of CoMix Wave Flims, the nepotistic self-fellation of him there makes now. Only 2 characters with no background or character traits of any kind beyond apparently having been classmates/friends with unvoiced crushes and 1 went off to be a space mecha pilot fighting aliens in space. These noncharacters fundamentally break the entire point of the movie centered around their star-crossed nonlove story of longing because it's all about their wanting to communicate over a long distance relationship despite the difficulty of time delay, yet NEITHER EVER ACTUALLY HAS ANYTHING TOSAY TO THE OTHER because these are noncharacters with nothing between them nor anything themselves to talk about. And it's not as if they couldn't just send messages pre-emptively most every day for each other rather than waiting around for a reply before sending a reply like idiots because again neither ever actually has anything to say.
And I'm not even going to give consideration to the idiotic Ender's Game mecha-action joke of a background plot rammed in alongside this nonromance story.

I'm not much of a writer and my english may be incorrect but bear with me please. This is one of the best hentai from bunny walker I have watched. Story is 9/10- this is hentai so the story is small but I love it, I need more vanilla type hentai like this. Art- 10/10, I have read its manga and the art is really good plus in animation as well. Not like queen bee Animation is 10/10, what can you expect from bunny walker or T-rex, they are literally the best hentai animators out there.Scenes - 10/10, I liked all

Characters- 10/10, I enjoyed this hentai more because of characters, love them all.

Overall- 9.7/10.

Definitely recommend to all of you, there's no ntr, no ugly bastards, no forced but absolutely Vanilla, romance with great animation and art styles.
I enjoyed it a lot now it's your time.

entry.title: Imaizumin Chi wa Douyara Gal no Tamariba ni Natteru Rashii

data.review:
It's a very shonen/action-focused anime. There really isn't much story nor anything meaningful explored beyond a series of mindless fights between various combinations of claymore warrior women and human-eating demon monsters. It never actually goes anywhere and just sort of reaches the end of the season still climbing that ladder as bait for the manga. The characters are barely allowed to have any presence beyond rehashing brain-damaging exposition/narration/peptalks and their 1-note character traits. The closest it comes to having actual characters in an arc gets unceremoniously cut through extreme contrivance. The plot armor is everywhere with pretty much every fight being nonsensical asspulls of more andmore powers being thrown in on top of the power of tryharding/friendship/love/etc to win from start to finish.
To be fair, as far as generic action-shonen go you could do much worse. At least this has some grittiness to it.

Lots of parts are very reminiscent of Laputa Castle in the Sky but this is far worse, really wastes 2 hours of screen time on barely anything. It's more like Shuna's Journey or The Boy and the Heron or The Cat Returns, hell even like Paradise Island or Atlantis or any other of a million stories just like it that journey into the mcguffin fantasy land to do the mcguffin thing. The problem is this doesn't do anything with it. It's a generic journey through the Underworld to save the dead lover noncharacter, and even lampshades itself as such. I'm confused why they decided to dosuch a 1-note story stretched over so much nothing that it develops neither characters nor much of anything beyond a bunch of pointless wandering, exposition, and chases, while simultaneously having almost nothing to say about anything beyond "nature is in fact what nature is."

It's not good. The scenes themselves are full of overexaggerated artificial feeling almost incessantly. The dub was poorly acted. The dialogue itself was terrible, mostly mindless exposition and self-narration and more grating artificiality.
The MC's motivations were nonsense, she constantly just follows everyone else around like a lost puppy before self-narrating that actually her character motivation is that she's lonely which is why she left her school friends and mother behind to go be alone listening to a radio in the mountains before following practical strangers into the Underworld to do whatever they want.

There are a lot of pointless side elements like the truth about the MC's father, or the fridge male who gets pointlessly replaced by his brother, or the background of a secret organization among other human organizations from history trying to pilfer the other world for knowledge (despite that they're simple medieval farmers and apparently none of the fantastical stuff had any effect on the world), or the gatekeepers (who are nothing more than plot devices and a hamfisted "pollution is bad" line), or the monster humanoids who can't eat the MC because endless plot armor... it's all pointless. None of it goes anywhere, none of it is meaningfully connected, it's just an uninspired series of events with decent animation quality much like the Earthsea anime movie. Even the radio voices referenced in the title in English have pretty much no relevance to the story itself, and the Japanese title means Children Who Chase Stars? There are 4 (really 3) children in this story and they mostly have barely any character nor importance to the plot and I could not for the life of me tell you why this movie is named the way it is in either language because their is only 1 child who barely happens to follow the voices mostly because an adult happened to lead her coincidentally that way and the voices turn out to be mostly irrelevant and dropped. And I guess because there are no stars in the magical Underworld it could be referencing the 1 child noncharacter fridge boy who wanted to see the outerworld where there are stars... which also has practically nothing to do with the movie.

3/10 (where 5/10 is average)

Send this poor, mentally ill/schizophrenic child to a non-quack doctor. That was genuinely what I was thinking for much of the movie, all the more by the end of it. This movie barely goes anywhere and is almost completely SoL filler aside from a single exposition dump dialogue scene. The plot, beyond irrelevant specifics, is extremely predictable and boring, relying on unearned heartstring pulling. No justice for boat guy's irrelevance to the movie. No point to random fat-shamed character. No point to random exposition dump art-lady. The plot of this movie is summarized in one minute of exposition dialogue and spends the entire rest of themovie insincerely baiting a shallow romance while tipping its hand on a pointless mystery that is hard to care about as they present it in the most excessively saccharine way.

A poorly written story of filler character drama to convey the very basic concept of escapism. Meanwhile, the memetic concept of Lil-Slugger and Maromi is maybe only in people's heads but also maybe real, while completely overlooking that the entire conflict of the entire story affecting the entirety of the city gets resolved immediately after fmc arbitrarily faces her trauma instead of resorting to escapism immediately after being confronted with it, and this one act immediately solves the entire memetic problem for everyone else, completely destroying the argument that it isn't a real entity. Pointless 2D character plotlines that go nowhere and haphazardly thrown in ideas andplot contrivances because it's just so cool that random old man is a plot contrivance doing math for no reason and random otaku exists and their dolls are maybe an autonomous ai program plot contrivance to have the police assistant to save the day and then become like the old man doing math for no reason and trust me the author says, this story is very deep because it pointlessly started with the empty ending scene of random escapism-inducing society stuff.

You have to look at older media through the lens of understanding that before modern internet there was a severe scarcity of porn such that any media depicting high-quality pornographic material wrapped within the veneer of a socially acceptable production would be regarded as a masterpiece. That is what has happened here with Soul(Ghost) in the Body(Shell) just like it did with A Clockwork Orange(A Machine in the Fruit, if you will). Getting to the actual review: How do we start? Director's masturbational intro cinematics of naked female body bodying (very important). Followed by long directorial vomit of self-indulgent concept art of the city in whichnothing happens. Oh-yeahh, waste my time harder, director daddy. Then they stumble through pointless stormtrooper action scenes and exposition dialogues of characters telling each other who they are and everything else they've already known about each other for the years they've worked together, interspersed by juvenile philosophical rambling that grapples with such worthwhile ideas as: 'How can one scientifically disprove that a machine isn't alive when one cannot scientifically define the arbitrary definitions of words?' and 'What is a person? I don't know.' By then over half the movie will be over and nothing of consequence will have happened. Then just finish it off with even more drawnout action sequence of stormtrooper bs and... I'm god of the machine now, k bye. The End.

This movie wasted so much potential of having such a well developed world from the manga, too bad the source material is episodic nonstories like this movie and the script writer is an amateur who couldn't cobble together much better.

It's fine, above average. It's a bit 1-note, hardly doing anything with such a fun premise. It didn't really have anything to say either so there isn't much to chew on for deeper meanings, it was merely spectacle done well on occasion (high budget cinematic art/animation and music). Which is fine, a story can be just a good spectacle to enjoy. But its main issue (aside from numerous dumb actions and contrivances throughout) was the large amount of mundane filler scenes (tons of pointless jobs) to pad the time in between anything of actual significance happening. Not intellectually stimulating, and not enough spectacle to be moresuperficially entertaining.

Subplots like the person behind the gun or the guys sexploiting underaged girls never went anywhere (they even had the police ignore criminals shouting unprompted "I didn't know they were underage, I swear!" which is... a pattern all too common in Japanese media)... I was really excited when the main mentor guy showed up out of nowhere at the end and seemed like he was about to reveal himself to be a horrible person behind both... but no... just randomly there for no reason so those plot points were just convenient plot devices tossed aside.

There's an entire scene where we follow 2 characters who exist solely in this 1 scene, solely to discover 1 specific little ramification of FMC's powers which none of the actual characters in the story will ever learn about. Bizarrely out of place.

The backstory with sunshine girl's mother was never explored to give her any significance for us to care at all (she's just dying lady in bed with no lines or even actions) yet it was the impetus for the entire premise of her powers. (Also dumb that her main motivation was to enjoy her last moments with her mother, yet she wanders off potentially leaving her mother to die alone because she saw a bit of sunlight shine through the clouds.)

The ending (even ignoring the dumb time skip) was super half-assed from start to finish.

There was quite a bit of product placement, especially an out of place McD's scene which was borderline false advertising, in a competition to suck as many corporations off along with a message about how 'rising water levels/climate change caused by humanity is fine so just let nature run its course.'
Plus the shameless, meaningless cameo of the MC of Your Name in a random family hiring the sunshine girl to try to ride the coat tails of its success.

Overall it is broad strokes almost a beat for beat alternate version of Your Name by the same writer, just with a different fantasy power premise and much less effort in the story/characters. (this girl exists as pretty much just dreamboat love interest for the mc to romance/save, whereas in Your Name she actually had a character of her own and agency helping to save herself and everyone). At least this movie was a bit better/more coherent than Suzume by the same writer (also with many of the same broad strokes).

Who is the audience for this? The BL is barely 2 goodbye pecks on the lips, and it's barely any romance overall with the leads being at best acquaintances who have almost no character consistency, wildly oscillating between: annoyance, abuser and enabler, friend, etc. on a dime, yet most of these characters who were actively going to slit others' throats will randomly become willing to give their lives to help them. All the characters are terrible, lacking in almost any personality beyond grumbling aside from the innocent goodboy non-character MC who may as well have been a golden retriever dog, at least then the timewasting filler dialoguewould've been avoided.
There's barely any sci-fi elements beyond random autonomous robot plot-contrivances used solely for chores and running messages rather than enforcing the 1984 surveillance government's control, and whatever sci-fi they attempt goes nowhere and instead becomes a nonsense plotline about some random fantasy nature deity who deus-ex-machinas the whole show in the end.
There's little action.
There's very little plot, outside the beginning and end the characters mostly just wander around doing filler like washing dogs, arguing about nothing, pulling up random plot threads that'll go nowhere... The actions of the cast didn't really have any relevance to the plot, the ending would've happened with or without them.

This show goes through so many of the same overall story beats as Fractale, except that anime did better in every way (though that is a low bar).

🌤The Sun Will Shine Again °7.4° °finishes strong with silver lining° 💯%🔍 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦Oota Kun must adjust to living with his brand new 👼🏻 sister, Mirai. Mirai gets all the attention🍼 so he battles with jealousy. He doesn't like Mirai... As his parents seem to only pay attention to him if he's in trouble, he's outside alone, and he finds some unexpected friends. These friends bring new insights into life, family, and what it all means. Here's a movie that I struggled to enjoy in the first half because I found all the characters unlikable. It wasn't until 2/3 of the film had passed that I could startto appreciate the ✨. The wrap up is lovely; by the time the credits rolled I was very pleased. This is a 🍭sweet film about a growing family.

M is a 98 minute English dubbed 2018 release by Studio Chizu that is rated 7.28 on MAL. It is not entirely unlike the feel of a Studio Ghilbi production; it's just a touch... darker? More realistic? Without reading up on it at all, it's obvious that the show is based on real-life dynamics. While it looks backwards in time, it is without the nostalgia that makes for Ghilbi magic. The author clearly 📝 from personal experience. They have the busy couple nailed🔨.

As M opens we meet Oota Kun, who until this morning was the only🤴🏻child in the homestead, but now he is a big brother. He is 3 or 4 years old and loves 🚇🚂🚆. He can be a brat. Oota goes on to have some touching experiences that promote his growth. Sure, there's setbacks, as growth is not a Maglev bullet train. It's more like learning to drive a standard transmission: Rolling backwards happens almost as much as moving forward. We all roll backwards at times.

Mom, for example, is a b!+ch, at times. That's fair: She's postpartum, she's tired, and she's clearly got alot on her mind. Did I mention she's tired? This is all part of the family-of-stressors that factor in when we make families. Mom later questions how good of a job she's doing❔ and if she's truly balancing everything❓❓ We also get to see mom when she was young - she's had a lot of growing up to do herself! M & D will talk later in the film about how she used to be angry all the time. They discuss how they've matured, and it's mostly because of the kids.

In typical opposites-attract contrast, dad is affable. Right now, mom just finds it /irritating/. Dad's easy-going nature also lends to letting others (mom) take the lead and handle the responsibilities. (Hence, mom is tired and stressed). The neighborhood women think dad is 😍 just /darling/. No doubt mom adored his laid-back nature when they were dating, but every good trait has its corresponding weakness. Women tend to l😑se their sense of humor in a marriage. There's plenty of good reasons for that, but still, it will hurt the woman and everyone around her. It's something to be mindful of. Even though I knew this, it still happened to me; I had to battle it. We'll learn what a caring person dad is. We also learn that dad's grandpa was H🔥T.

The primary theme is: Parents - it's going to get better. In addition to that, Oota has some huge 📶steps to climb when this movie opens: He's got big life changes going on. He comes to understand what family is and also manages to be brave and he learns. The first 👣 towards maturity is learning that we are not the center of the universe. Maturity is learning to be unselfish. Steps, consequently, are featured in about half of the frames, it seems. That can't be an accident.

The art🎨 is lovely. There's some train animation that is stunning. On a reality scale out of 10, people are drawn at about a 6.7 and backgrounds at around a 6 - simplified realism. It fits the theme perfectly.

One of the biggest benefits of M would be in preparing a younger child to share attention with a sibling. 🚧 Parents of preschoolers and primary aged kids < 7, be aware: Ota has a nightmare where he calls to his mom's back and when she turns her head, it's a devil👺face. Other things might scare children, like when, in a dreamlike sequence, he gets lost at the train station. He may be forced to take the train to Lonely Land.

Oota loses his temper and hits his sister out of anger and jealousy. Some parents will see this as an opportunity for instruction, while others wouldn't want their children "getting⚠ideas". There's kids that are living in the same house with the same parents that would not benefit from the same choice between 'watch or don't watch'. So decide the best you can as to what age is appropriate to watch this.
